The sheaf condition on top spaces can be phrased in a rather succint way, namely that for every open covering {Ui}i\{U_i\}_i{Ui​}i​ (of an open set UUU), F(colim⁡Ui)≅lim⁡F(Ui)F(\operatorname{colim} U_i) \cong \operatorname{lim} F(U_i)F(colimUi​)≅limF(Ui​).
I was wondering... is this true for any site? So let 'open covering' be replaced by 'covering sieve' in the above sentence. I'm quite convinced F(U)≅lim⁡F(Ui)F(U) \cong \operatorname{lim} F(U_i)F(U)≅limF(Ui​) for a sheaf, not so much that colim⁡Ui≅U\operatorname{colim} U_i \cong UcolimUi​≅U.
Indeed, the coincidence relies on the Grothendieck topology being canonical, I think
:thinking: It seems a reasonable characterization.

The condition colim Ui≃U⇒F(colim Ui)≃F(U)\mathrm{colim} \,U_i \simeq U \Rightarrow F(\mathrm{colim} \, U_i ) \simeq F(U)colimUi​≃U⇒F(colimUi​)≃F(U) does not depend on the Grothendieck topology. So, for an arbitrary Grothendieck topology, it is not equivalent to the sheaf condition.

You can modify your criterion a bit:
colim a(Ui)≃a(U)⇒lim F(Ui)≃F(U)\mathrm{colim} \, \mathbf{a}(U_i) \simeq \mathbf{a}(U) \Rightarrow \mathrm{lim} \, F(U_i ) \simeq F(U)colima(Ui​)≃a(U)⇒limF(Ui​)≃F(U).
Here a\mathbf{a}a denotes first taking Yoneda embedding and then sheafifying.

I think this is equivalent to the sheaf condition for an arbitrary Grothendieck topology. The reason is that a covering sieve SSS of UUU can be interpreted as a sub-presheaf of y(U)\mathbf{y}(U)y(U), and sheafification makes sure that the inclusion S⊆y(U)S \subseteq \mathbf{y}(U)S⊆y(U) becomes an isomorphism.
I'm a bit puzzled, why colim⁡F(Ui)\operatorname{colim} F(U_i)colimF(Ui​) and not lim⁡\operatorname{lim}lim?
Also I don't understand the implication. If colim⁡Ui≠U\operatorname{colim} U_i \neq UcolimUi​=U I still want FFF so satisfy a sheaf condition on that covering sieve
Finally, why would I want the inclusion S⊆yUS \subseteq yUS⊆yU to be an iso?

Matteo Capucci said:

Finally, why would I want the inclusion S⊆yUS \subseteq yUS⊆yU to be an iso?

You can describe sheaves as the local objects with respect to the maps S⊆yUS \subseteq yUS⊆yU, so after sheafification these are isos.
:thinking: I see
Btw using sheafification to define the sheaf condition kind of defeats the point of my question, since then it's easier to say FFF is a sheaf if F≅aFF \cong aFF≅aF
I think it's fine to stick with F(U)≅lim⁡F(Ui)F(U) \cong \operatorname{lim} F(U_i)F(U)≅limF(Ui​)

Then I see that the left hand side is always true, since as you and @Kenji Maillard remarked, sheafification makes it work

Matteo Capucci said:

Then I see that the left hand side is always true, since as you and Kenji Maillard remarked, sheafification makes it work

Yes, for a sieve S={Ui→U}i∈IS = \{ U_i \to U \}_{i \in I}S={Ui​→U}i∈I​, the left hand side is equivalent to SSS being a covering sieve. So instead of the criterion I wrote down, you can just say instead that FFF is a sheaf if and only if F(U)=lim F(Ui)F(U) = \mathrm{lim}\, F(U_i)F(U)=limF(Ui​) for each covering sieve.
:thumbs_up:

Fabrizio Genovese said:

If I'm not wrong this is in Sheaves in Geometry and Logic, somewhere between Chapters 1 and 3

I couldn't find M&M explicitly using this characterization. They provide a different definition of sheaf on a site, which is one such that for every covering sieve SSS on UUU (= open covering) and any α:S→F\alpha :S \to Fα:S→F (= a compatible family of sections on the covering), there is a unique extension of α\alphaα along the inclusion S↣yUS \rightarrowtail yUS↣yU (= a global section)

By definition/Yoneda, "colim a(Ai)=a(A)\mathrm{colim}\, \mathbf{a}(A_i) = \mathbf{a}(A)colima(Ai​)=a(A)" means exactly "for every sheaf FFF, FA=lim⁡F(Ai)FA = \lim F(A_i)FA=limF(Ai​)". This doesn't use anything about sheaves other than that they are a reflexive subcategory of presheaves with reflector a\mathbf{a}a.
In particular the phenomena discussed here don't have anything to do with sheaves per se--the same happens in any localization.

Yes, the M&M definition says in other words that the natural transformation Hom(yU,−)→Hom(S,−)Hom(yU,-)\to Hom(S,-)Hom(yU,−)→Hom(S,−) is an isomorphism, when the second argument takes values in the subcategory of sheaves. So by the adjunction and Yoneda, you get that a(S)→a(yU)\mathbf{a}(S) \to \mathbf{a}(yU)a(S)→a(yU) is an isomorphism.

It is important here that you work with sieves, not just with covering families.

For example, the map Spec(C)→Spec(R)\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{C}) \to \mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{R})Spec(C)→Spec(R) is a covering map for the étale topology. But the colimit of Spec(C)\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{C})Spec(C), as a diagram with one object, is equal to Spec(C)\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{C})Spec(C) itself.

On the other hand, if you take the sieve generated by Spec(C)→Spec(R)\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{C}) \to \mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{R})Spec(C)→Spec(R), then you get that the colimit of this sieve is equal to Spec(R)\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{R})Spec(R), in the étale topos.

The sieve stuff is more subtle--the map S→yUS \to yUS→yU is the "inclusion of the image" part of the map of presheaves colim yUi→yU\mathrm{colim}\,y U_i \to y UcolimyUi​→yU and for some reason which I don't recall at the moment, but I think is rather specific to the situation of (1-)topoi, it's equivalent to impose the locality condition with respect to the map from the sieve.
(Probably not on a per-map basis, but for the whole coverage at once, or something like that.)
I guess everyone has been a bit vague about what the index category in "colim yUi\mathrm{colim}\,yU_icolimyUi​" is exactly.

Ah right, this criterion
colim a(Ui)≃a(U)⇒lim F(Ui)≃F(U)\mathrm{colim} \, \mathbf{a}(U_i) \simeq \mathbf{a}(U) \Rightarrow \mathrm{lim} \, F(U_i ) \simeq F(U)colima(Ui​)≃a(U)⇒limF(Ui​)≃F(U)
is equivalent to the sheaf condition by @Reid Barton's argument, and you don't even need that {Ui→U}i∈I\{U_i \to U\}_{i \in I}{Ui​→U}i∈I​ is a sieve.
The only problem is that a "covering map" like Spec(C)→Spec(R)\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{C})\to\mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{R})Spec(C)→Spec(R) does not necessarily satisfy the criterion on the left hand side. A covering sieve always does though.
